text: A little disappointed and the rain didn't help.  The trip to Ganvie village was interesting, crossing people going to or from the market or fishermen working their nets.  But once we got to Ganvie, we were offloaded unto a crowded plaza with a souvenir shop.

title: "The Venice of Africa"
text:
Ganvie, Benin is a stilt city on Lac Nokoue, and is better known as the "Venice of Africa."The only way to see this community, of 22,000 residents, is by boat. We were a group was 30 people so we went in 2 boats. The scenery was amazing... residents in their boats going home with supplies, men fishing, 
the mangroves, and buildings. When I asked our guide why these residents lived on the lake she stated, that they were escaping from Africans who were trying to capture them and sell them to Europeans to enslave them. They were never enslaved. Many residents spoke to us, but many did not want their pictures taken. There is a store where you purchase souvenirs, clothing, as well as drinks. Enjoyed this visit in Benin!

title: Zaludnione jezioro .
text: To było jedno z większych zaskoczeń . Mieliśmy odwiedzić wioskę zbudowaną na palach . Okazało się ,że to tysiące bambusowych chatek ale także większych obiektów należących do plemienia Tofinu. Wioska powstała już w XVII wieku . Taki był pomysł plemienia na bezpieczne schronienie min. przed handlarzami niewolników. Ta rozległa wieś na wodzie wygląda niesamowicie .Przez wieki wytworzyła się tu specyficzna symbioza ludzi z jeziorem Nokoue .Transport wodny jest tu rozpowszechniony we wszystkich możliwych wariantach. On też jest  podstawą normalnego funkcjonowania dużej wsi zamieszkanej przez ok .30 tyś ludzi . Na terenie wsi zobaczyć można również duże betonowe budowle takie jak szkoły , meczet czy kościół chrześcijański .Jest oczywiście targ na wodzie , punkt poboru wody pitnej , wodny ambulans restauracje i hoteliki .Miejsce czasem nazywane jest "Wenecją Afryki Zachodniej" ale mi bardziej kojarzy się z Azją . Miejsce na pewno warte odwiedzin . Przy przystani jest biuro prywatnej firmy która zajmuje się transportem wodnym. Wszyscy od dzieci szkolnych po turystów muszą płacić za przepłynięcie z wioski do przystani .Szczegółowa taryfa uwzględnia różne warianty w zależności od  ilości osób i czasu skorzystania z łodzi .

title: Magnifico giro
text: Una visita a Ganvié vale assolutamente la pena. Ho girato solo il sud del Benin, ma non c'è dubbio che sia il luogo che più mi ha colpito. Si arriva al villaggio lacustre solo in barca. Le case, i negozi e la scuola ecc sono tutti su palafitte. Il mercato galleggiante sulle barche. Dove c'è terreno, l'hanno creato per insegnare ai bimbi a camminare. Un'esperienza unica e affascinante.

Dove c'è terreno, l'hanno creato per insegnare ai bimbi a camminare. Un'esperienza unica e affascinante.

title: Interessante Tour
text:
Über Gozem habe ich mir ein Motortaxi zur Ganvie boat station bestellt - 850 cfa. Die Fahrt dauert nur 30 Minuten. Eine Stunde Fahrt mit dem Motorboot kostet 10.000 cfa und mit den Ruderboot (1,5h) 8.000 cfa. Nach 30 Minuten kamen noch andere Touristen - zwei Chinesen. Dadurch habe ich nur 5.050 cfa - Motorboot mit englischsprachigen Guide bezahlt. 
Die Fahrt durch das Stelzendorf war interessant und zugleich war aus beeindruckend was alles auf den Booten transportiert wird. Wir konnten auch viele Fischer sehen. Viele Fotos habe ich nicht gemacht, da ich den Eindruck hatte, dass einige nicht fotografiert werden wollten. Auf der Fahrt haben wir noch einen kurzen Stopp bei einem Souvenirshop gemacht - zwei Schlüsselanhänger 3000 cfa. Es gibt sicherlich bessere Souvenirsshops. 
Rückzu konnte ich leider kein Gozem bestellen (Die App funktioniert nur in Cotounou) und musste ein normales Motortai nehmen: 1.500 cfa.

title: Pleasant surprise
text: I went there for work and has no expectation. Hence I was very surprised by how nice and vibrant the place was. So much to see between floating markets, houses, fishing areas, etc. They even have some hotels and small gift shops with locally made stuff (good way to support the local community). Great day out

title: Stilt village of Ganvie
text: Managed to organize a boat through Edouard Houmenou +229 96311011 who also acted as a tour guide for our trip and was very knowledgable about the different floating markets, fishing techniques and different villages on the lake including Ganvie. The docks are about 45 minutes from Cotonou so it's an easy day trip. Edouard arranged to take us to a village at the far end of the lake called Dekanmey which has a diety which protects the residents from ligthning. Great trip but unfortunately it rained in the morning the day the trip was organized and there was overcast skies most of the day.

title: Ganvie sur le lac Noukoue  Un joyaux en précarité !
text:
Le lac Nokoue .est le plus grand lac du Bénin (20 sur 10 km) il est situé dans le Sud et la capitale économique Cotonou.est établie entre ses rives et l'océan.  Un canal lagunaire ouvert par les français en 1885 a bouleversé son écosystème ,qui est donc de l'eau saumâtre au Sud en période de basses eaux . Il est alimenté en eau douce par la rivière Oueme qui descend des montagnes du Nord et qui se jette dans la lagune de Porto Novo à l'Est qui se déverse dans  le lac par une jonction .

Ganvie ,cité lacustre est située au Nord du lac et l'on y accède par barques de l'embarcadère de Calavi . Il convient de négocier le prix de la prestation et de conclure sur des bases claires pour éviter les recours de suppléments au retour.
Avec le Covid ,le site a été partiellement délaissé par les touristes et les prestataires  hôtel et restaurant sur place n'ont pas tous remis leur établissement en état fonctionnel . Les chambres d'hôtel n'ont pas toutes le confort minimum et peuvent décevoir ! Les deux restaurants ouverts ont le minimum à vous offrir poisson et poulet avec accompagnement riz frites pommes sautées.
Après un court trajet pour se rendre sur place , on découvre un peu tout et n'importe quoi .
Les cases sont construites sur pilotis et ne sont pas flottantes ce qui leur donne parfois un air de guingois . Les toitures initialement en chaume ont été remplacées par de la tôle souvent rouillée. Assez peu de cases sont en  état et certaines menacent ruine. Tout ça pour dire que ce joyaux dépérit et que l'état qui prône le développement touristique serait bien inspiré de s'y intéresser

Ceci dit ,il y a des choses
Intéressantes à voir comme le marché flottant  où se rassemblent les vendeuses en barques, les cases colorées ou le cadre est valorise  Les enfants qui rentrent de l'ecole en barque et en chanson. Les centres de distribution.d'eau potable où se rassemblent les habitants dans leur barque.

Ici on trouve aussi une église et une mosquée ,la poste ,une administration municipale, etc 
Nous avons déjeuné chez Madame M au carrefour . Le poulet était vivant et il a du subir tous les préparatifs pour atterrir dans notre assiette ,fraîcheur garantie mais 1 heure d'attente de la
Terrasse à observer le trafic dans Ganvie. Le poulet, qui est bicyclette, s'est défendu mais on a réussi à en venir à bout avec du riz à 5000 fr la part.
translated_title: Ganvie on Lake Noukoue A jewel in precariousness!
translated_text: Lake Nokoue is the largest lake in Benin (20 by 10 km). It is located in the South and the economic capital Cotonou is established between its shores and the ocean. A lagoon canal opened by the French in 1885 disrupted its ecosystem, which is therefore brackish water in the South during periods of low water. It is supplied with fresh water by the Oueme River which descends from the mountains in the North and flows into the Porto Novo lagoon in the East which flows into the lake through a junction. Ganvie, a lakeside town is located to the North of the lake and is accessed by boat from the Calavi pier. It is advisable to negotiate the price of the service and conclude on clear bases to avoid recourse to supplements on return. With Covid, the site has been partially abandoned by tourists and the hotel and restaurant providers on site have not all restored their establishments to operational condition. The hotel rooms do not all have the minimum comfort and can disappoint! The two open restaurants have the minimum to offer you fish and chicken with a side of rice, fries, sautéed potatoes. After a short trip to get there, you discover a little bit of everything and anything. The huts are built on stilts and are not floating, which sometimes gives them a crooked look. The roofs, initially thatched, have been replaced by often rusty sheet metal. Very few huts are in good condition and some are threatening ruin. All this to say that this jewel is dying and that the state, which advocates tourist development, would be well advised to take an interest in it. That said, there are interesting things to see, such as the floating market where the vendors gather in boats, the colorful huts where the setting is enhanced. The children returning from school in boats and singing. The drinking water distribution centers where the inhabitants gather in their boats. Here we also find a church and a mosque, the post office, a municipal administration, etc. We had lunch at Madame M's at the crossroads. The chicken was alive and had to go through all the preparations to land on our plate, freshness guaranteed but 1 hour of waiting on the Terrace watching the traffic in Ganvie. The chicken, which is a bicycle, defended itself but we managed to overcome it with rice at 5000 fr a portion.

title: Great excursion from Cotonou
text: Depending on traffic, you get quickly to the departure point from Cotonou. A great 1hour+ outing to see how people live every day on the water and what their live looks like in 'The Venice of Africa'.
translated_text: Depending on traffic, you get quickly to the departure point from Cotonou. A great 1hour+ outing to see how people live every day on the water and what their live looks like in 'The Venice of Africa'.

title: SUBLIME
text: La balade à pirogue sur le lac Nokoué autour du village lacustre de Ganvié est absolument incontournable, magique. Au cœur du Bénin, vous partirez à la découverte d'un endroit surprenant et touchant. Certes, on peut se sentir un peu voyeur mais c'est aussi le propre du tourisme. Mérite plus qu'un détour mais au contraire une journée complète et un repas sur place (Chez Raphael par exemple)
translated_text: The pirogue ride on Lake Nokoué around the lakeside village of Ganvié is absolutely unmissable, magical. In the heart of Benin, you will discover a surprising and touching place. Sure, you can feel a bit like a voyeur, but that's also the nature of tourism. It deserves more than a detour, but on the contrary, a full day and a meal on site (Chez Raphael for example).

title: Highlight of my weekend off work
text: Well worth a trip to this interesting village with all buildings on stilt over the lake.  Went with a local so no trouble finding dock for boats or negotiating price.  Fees really minimal and a bargain if going in a group since boat was a flat rate.  Our boat had a young man who offered to act as a guide "for whatever we wished to pay"  though there was a suggestion of CFA5000 - less than $10. Stanislaus said he was a resident, told us all about the history and explained how the fishing works.  Was open to any question and though he spoke very little English he spoke slowly in clear French making most of the tour understandable to my limited French.  Only two stops to shop and nothing at all pushy in either place.  They were pleasant interludes.  All in all a fascinating half day visit in a country not long on things to do in down time/

title: Ganvié, Magnifique !
text:
Visite à Ganvié, La Venise d'Afrique ou le temps semble s'être arreté et pourtant..
C'est un moment très fort, émouvant que nous avons vécu en famille. Ce peuple qui a fui pour ne pas être esclave, pour survivre et vivre librement. Un paysage à couper le souffle. Qui sont ces gens? Comment font-ils pour vivre ainsi? Comment ferions nous à leur place? Tant de questions...Certains nous soutiennent du regard, d'autres ne veulent pas être photographié. Les regards, les bouilles et les sourires des enfants m'ont ému comme jamais. Leurs aurevoirs et leurs saluts me suffisent. Ces images resteront gravées à jamais. Comment rester insensible devant ce spectacle, devant l'essence de la vie?
translated_text: Visit to Ganvié, the Venice of Africa where time seems to have stopped and yet... It was a very powerful, moving moment that we experienced as a family. These people who fled to avoid being enslaved, to survive and live freely. A breathtaking landscape. Who are these people? How do they manage to live like this? How would we do in their place? So many questions... Some support us with their eyes, others do not want to be photographed. The looks, the faces and the smiles of the children moved me like never before. Their goodbyes and their hellos are enough for me. These images will remain etched forever. How can one remain indifferent to this spectacle, to the essence of life?

title: Voyage dans un autre univers!
text: Quelle magnifique balade dans ce village lacustre! Ces maisons sur pilotis, ces jacinthes d'eau à la fois belles et envahissantes, ces visages souriants et ces embarcations colorées... Le commerce est très présent, mais cela reste sympa!
translated_text: What a wonderful stroll through this lakeside village! These houses on stilts, these water hyacinths, both beautiful and invasive, these smiling faces and these colorful boats... There is a lot of commerce, but it's still nice!

title: Amazing To Witness
text: Ganvie is a lake village in Benin, Africa lying in Lake Nokoué, near Cotonou. With a population of around 20,000 people, it is probably the largest lake village in Africa. The locals aren't fond of photos. I traveled solo and was able to negotiate a fair price with one of the boat operators.
translated_text: Ganvie is a lake village in Benin, Africa lying in Lake Nokoué, near Cotonou. With a population of around 20,000 people, it is probably the largest lake village in Africa. The locals aren't fond of photos. I traveled solo and was able to negotiate a fair price with one of the boat operators.

title: Promenade en pirogue, repas copieux et dépaysant assuré
text:
Après être montés dans une pirogue, laissez vous conduire dans cette Venise béninoise et allez à la rencontre de cette cité lacustre de 40000 habitants vivants tous sur le Lac Nokoue où les activités de pêche, d'élevage, de commerce en tout genre se déroulent. Quel incroyable spectacle !
Des petits établissements permettent de se restaurer sur place. Attention aux tarifs qui parfois sont exagérément élevés.
Pensez au chapeau de paille tressé avant d'embarquer - achat possible sur le parking dès l'arrivée
translated_title: Canoe trip, hearty meal and a change of scenery guaranteed
translated_text: After boarding a canoe, let yourself be driven to this Beninese Venice and discover this lakeside city of 40,000 inhabitants, all living on Lake Nokoue, where fishing, livestock farming, and all kinds of trade take place. What an incredible spectacle! Small establishments offer on-site dining. Be careful of prices, which can sometimes be excessively high. Remember to bring a woven straw hat before boarding - you can buy it in the parking lot upon arrival.

title: Un salto in un “altrove”
text: Una piroga per andare al mercato, incontrare gli amici, andare a scuola. Non esiste altro per muoversi e socializzare nel villaggio di Ganvie. Costruito su palafitte da chi scappava dai mercanti di schiavi questo villaggio di 10.000 persone offre scorci magnifici e una esperienza interessante. Anche qui non amano essere fotografati.
translated_text: Una piroga per andare al mercato, incontrare gli amici, andare a scuola. Non esiste altro per muoversi e socializzare nel villaggio di Ganvie. Costruito su palafitte da chi scappava dai mercanti di schiavi questo villaggio di 10.000 persone offre scorci magnifici e una esperienza interessante. Anche qui non amano essere fotografati.

title: A lively place with folks going about life.
text: Our group took a private water taxi from a fishing dock in Cotonou. Many folks in our group had toured similar stilt villages in Asia and other parts of Africa. We felt welcomed and the folks treated us well. We always asked before taking a picture. Despite the circumstances of their dwellings many of the houses were painted in bright colors.We were also fascinated by the lively water commerce, that is, women in small boats plying the water selling household products and men in similar boats selling fish. We stopped at a small auberge for drinks and souvenirs. Our tour lasted about 90 minutes.

title: A worthwhile day trip from Cotonou
text:
We decided to go by private taxi instead of using the public transport - it was only 7000 cfa return, so if are 3 or 4, it is approximately the same price, much quicker and hassle free. Our taxi waited for us until we were back, otherwise it is 4000 cfa one way.
The trip itself is interesting, do take a covered pirogue since the scorching sun is vicious.
I would like to recommend as a guide Benjamin KOUNOU,  +229-97094940. Very knowledgeable, patient, civilized and not pushy at all (unlike some of the others we encountered). You can also write to him in advance (Benjaminkounou@gmail.com). he will meet you and take care of the whole process. Recommended !!

title: interessante escursione
text:
Tutta la vita si svolge sulle piroghe, dai commerci al tragitto per andare a scuola.
L'escursione in barca tra le case di palafitte è interessante, anche se l'accompagnatore non spiega pressoché nulla del luogo e talvolta ci si sente di invadere la privacy dei locali. 
Suggestivo il mercato sull'acqua che si svolge prima dell'alba, suoni e atmosfera lo distinguono da altri mercati simili in Asia.

title: Ok but not what I expected
text: The stilt village was not really what I expected. Interesting although its a bit run down. Felt a bit unwelcome as the people living there were not very friendly and it’s clear that people do not like to be photographed, although that’s understandable. Not as picturesque as I expected. An hour visit is enough.
translated_title: Ok but not what I expected
translated_text: The stilt village was not really what I expected. Interesting although its a bit run down. Felt a bit unwelcome as the people living there were not very friendly and it’s clear that people do not like to be photographed, although that’s understandable. Not as picturesque as I expected. An hour visit is enough.

title: totally love this place
text: Ganvie is a place to visit. it is a place like Venice but not as popular as them. The beautiful sights of boats ,the village houses blew me away. u need to take a boat there but it was  totally worth it when you reach there. the market and the people  there were very bubbly and seeing these people living in these places is facinating. i am sure i will get a great sunset or sunrise if i stay there, and the fish i order there was one of the best i ever had in west africa.on the journey back to the mainland,u can see boats of different type going back to Ganvie after they finish selling their products in the market :) one of the highlight of my west africa trip. i hoped ths place will get the limelight of its beauty

title: Visite à faire absolument
text: Le lac de Nokoue est surtout intéressant pour la visite de la cité lacustre de Ganvié. Cette ville de 30000 habitants qui prend son origine à la traite des esclaves qui se sont réfugiés sur le lac pour échapper à leur vente, est la plus grande cité lacustre d'Afrique. La visite se fait en bateau avec un guide à partir du rivage. On traverse les parcelles où les pêcheurs piègent les poissons (unique ressource économique de la ville). Après 15/20 minutes de traversé, on arrive à la ville. Toutes les activités sont présentes: magasins, écoles, lieux de culte, hôtel, centre de santé. Tout ceci dans des maisons sur pilotis plus ou moins bien conservées. Les habitants vous accueillent avec le sourire mais surtout respectez les en ne prenant pas de photos des visages. Le guide va vous emmener dans des magasins de souvenirs. Acceptez même si vous n'achetez rien. La promenade se fait à travers les canaux. Quelques ilots artificiels ont été créé et une vraie ile est présente (elle est à l'origine de la ville).
translated_text: Lake Nokoue is especially interesting for visiting the lakeside town of Ganvié. This town of 30,000 inhabitants, which dates back to the slave trade, which took refuge on the lake to escape being sold, is the largest lakeside town in Africa. The tour is done by boat with a guide from the shore. You cross the plots where fishermen trap fish (the town's only economic resource). After a 15/20 minute crossing, you arrive at the town. All the activities are present: shops, schools, places of worship, hotel, health center. All this in more or less well-preserved houses on stilts. The locals welcome you with a smile, but above all, respect them by not taking photos of their faces. The guide will take you to souvenir shops. Accept even if you don't buy anything. The walk is through the canals. Some artificial islets have been created and a real island is present (it is the origin of the town).

title: Ganvie, the neat town on the water
text:
This town on the water has a lot of history to share so do not just look for a boat,  get a guide who will answer your questions correctly.
As a tour guide and operator, when ever I bring tourists on this trip, I like to talk about the neatness of the people.
Questions will unfold on your mind as you experience nature and culture.

title: Fascinating stilt village
text: This stilt village is definitely worth a visit. It's fascinating to see how everything is navigated on the water and is far more authentic than other stilt villages that I've visited. The fishing areas were also interesting, as we learned that they are owned and passed down through the family line. There is enough boat time from the port to the middle of the village to both enjoy the sights and take photos. There is also an opportunity to stay there as we saw a few guesthouses. Try to get there early to experience people leaving and coming into the port.

title: Vaste lac
text: Ce lac est immense. Il couvre plus de 200km2 et est le plus grand lac du bénin et lun des plus grand d'Afrique. La pêche est une de ses principales activités.
translated_text: This lake is immense. It covers more than 200 km2 and is the largest lake in Benin and one of the largest in Africa. Fishing is one of its main activities.

title: It is very picturesque
text: I always feel a little guilty observing peoples normal everyday lives as a tourist attraction but if that helps the local economy then that must be good?  The trouble here with the locals not really being smiley or welcoming is that perhaps they do not benefit from tourism and so resent being photographed. Anyway, it is very picturesque and a great insight into a different way of living. And normal and everyday it is, from first light people were using the waterway as other people use roads and from our hotel dining area we could see people were rowing boats, selling goods, chatting to neighbours.................

title: Interesting way of life
text: The great thing about travel is that you see such different ways of life. This is an interesting lifestyle and yes, in answer, to the Singaporan this is a giant sewer. It's how some people live and far more interesting than the over clean Singapore. It's not the locals who are rude. We as tourists intrude on their life. We do not have a good given right to poke our cameras in everyone's faces. We have to respect their culture. How would you like someone In your front room taking your picture!

title: A tourist trap
text:
11JAN18.  I have travelled all over the world and this review is really for English speaking solo travellers.  BTW i speak French and it was still a challenge.  I found a co-traveller and we went from our hotel to Etoile by taxi-moto (pillion rider on a motorbike). Pay no more than CFA500. We only paid 300CFA. At Etoile find a share taxi to Calavi (pay only 500CFA) to the point near Ganvié.  Taxi motos will be waiting to grab u. Tell them no need and it is a 5min walk to the entry point.  Again u will have sharks waiting to grab u.  We paid 4500CFA as we were two.  There's a board with the rates.  Buy the ticket in the office.  Having read previous reviews, we decided we did not need a guide. The place stinks and people are unfriendly.  Dont try taking photos as they get aggressive.  I had to tell one cow on the canoe (pirogue in french) that i was not photographing her but the scenary. The boat guy was a diffentently challenged with a leg deformity.  I thought - "great that he has employment and my heart strings were being pulled. He took us to the entrance to the stilt village to a cafe/souvenir shop and said if we wanted to go further, we had to get another pirogue.  The entrance is called Marché collectif where women sell vegetables etc from the boats.  We told him that the price we paid was to do the "citrcuit de village".  He refused and said he was tired and did not want to row back.  He would put us on a collective boat which the people of the village take to reach land.  When you are out in the boons, there are no officers there to complain.  U just have to get back to the port entry.  We did and I went straight to the office to complain.  I threatened them that i will be putting this on the internet for other travellers and they panicked.  They shouted at the boat guy and asked us to write a complaint.  This is africa and i was not going to waste any more time as we lost 2 hours already.

I suggest that you try and join a group of tourists on a  motor boat. Or go as a package tour.  If u still do the pirogue, ensure that the circuit is to the interiors of the village and not just the entrance.I can understand the local frustration as the government takes the CFA4500.  We could not figure out how the boat guy got paid. After travelling to Cote D'Ivoire, Burkina Faso, Togo and Benin, this was the first place where u get stares from the locals and no "bonjour".  One has to wonder where the human refuse is saved or is it just one big sewer?

If u want to see a really nice stilt village, go to Bandar Seri Begawan in Brunei.  U can walk along the houses on paths on stilts. This is my personal experience and facts.  You can decide.  BTW I'm a brown skin and so not white enough to be taken for a ride.

title: Un pittoresco villaggio su palafitte in mezzo al lago.
text: Il lago Nokoue bagna la città di Abomey-Calavi da una parte e il villaggio di Ganvie dall'altra. Il lago non è molto profondo e ha una flora e una fauna che assomigliano a quelle dei delta di alcuni fiumi europei: aironi e canne. Sul lago transitano varie imbarcazioni, a motore quelle che trasportano i turisti, a remi quelle degli abitanti. Le barche dei residenti assomigliano ai sandali veneziani, sono leggére e di legno. Adatte al trasporto di merci e persone, reggono bene i continui urti. Giunti in uno qualunque degli hotel spartani, ci si accomoda su qualche terrazza per assistere al passaggio delle barche. Ma quello che desta maggior stupore sono le abitazioni: osservandole viene da chiedersi come possano stare su poggiando solo su quattro pali di legno. Io ho pernottato a Ganvie, ma tutto sommato non ne vale la pena, perché dopo il tramonto il traffico delle barche si interrompe e in certe stagioni le zanzare non danno tregua. Nonostante l'acqua stagnante l'umidità è sopportabile.

title: Tick
text: If you're in Cotonou, you have got to go to Ganvie, I suppose. It IS interesting to see, although most of the residents don't seem particularly keen to see you.
translated_text: If you're in Cotonou, you have got to go to Ganvie, I suppose. It IS interesting to see, although most of the residents don't seem particularly keen to see you.

title: Vaut le détour
text: Nous avons visité Ganvié depuis Abomey Calavi. La balade est très sympa, le village de Ganvié vaut vraiment le détour. Par contre, attention aux guides qui peuvent chercher à vous arnaquer. Notre guide voulait nous réclamer 2000 F de plus pour revenir à Abomey Calavi, car selon lui on ne peut pas revenir à la rame et qu'il faut payer la pirogue à moteur. Il faut bien faire préciser le prix avant d'embarquer et ce qui est compris. Pour information, le prix de la balade à Ganvié en pirogue à rame est 4050F par personne et 5050F par personne pour une pirogue à moteur. Il faut ajouter 5000F pour le guide.
translated_text: We visited Ganvié from Abomey Calavi. The walk is very nice, the village of Ganvié is definitely worth the detour. However, beware of guides who may try to scam you. Our guide wanted to ask us for 2000 F more to return to Abomey Calavi, because according to him we cannot return by rowing and we have to pay for the motorized canoe. You must clearly specify the price before boarding and what is included. For your information, the price of the trip to Ganvié in a rowing canoe is 4050 F per person and 5050 F per person for a motorized canoe. You must add 5000 F for the guide.

title: Une expérience unique
text: On a passé une heure et demie en pirogue entre les différents maisons sur pilotis et c'était juste magnifique. Un endroit hors norme et unique. Voir ces gens vivre, se déplacer, vendre et acheter, étudier sur le lac est juste exceptionnel. À visiter absolument.
translated_text: We spent an hour and a half in a canoe between the various houses on stilts and it was just magnificent. An extraordinary and unique place. Seeing these people living, moving, selling and buying, and studying on the lake is simply exceptional. A must-see.

title: A must do for all benin visitors
text: Most likely the most touristy place in whole Benin, but definitly worth a visit. I went twice. Find a good local guide. 2 to 4 hour tour is enough. It's really nice to see how a whole community lives on water. Quiet unique. Be respectful when taking pictures. Not all locals like having their picture taken, some want money for it.

It's really nice to see how a whole community lives on water. Quiet unique. Be respectful when taking pictures. Not all locals like having their picture taken, some want money for it.

title: One of the few tourist destinations in Benin and a good place to visit and relax
text: You take a boat a the embarcadiere de Abomey-Calavi, pay 5000 per person or less if you are with more, and off you go. You get a guide with you but information he tells is limited. In the village you make the required stops at some restaurants befriended by the guide and at some shops. All in all you can spent 2-4 hours at the lake. It might be nicer if you take the non motorized pirogues, well definitely give you a more relaxed feeling.

title: Discovery of a hidden African jewel
text:
Pretty much incredible to discover a village on the lake where inhabitants are living on houses in the middle of the lake and circulating with pirogue where you need to swim or paddle to have a beer with your neighbor !
When kids are a few years old, parents bring them to the ground in order for them to learn walking differently from boarding boats and walking around the house !
Spending the night in the village is a good option to feel this so special atmosphere.
As often in Africa, hidden beauties are waiting to be discovered.

title: excellent visit
text:
Extremely interesting place to visit.  I have visited similar villages located on stilts in Laos and Brunei and this was still a very enjoyable time. I highly recommend you stay at night at one of the few hotels in Ganvier and dont just visit in a quick day trip.

One interesting view is the locals attitudes towards tourists in general.  My guide who was from Ghana had noticed the same thing.  It is very rare to get a smile from a local as you cruise by each other in boats.  Most of the time in west africa when you pass a stranger and smile and wave you get a smile and wave back 98% of the time. Here in Ganvier maybe 25%.  The villagers are very suspicious of tourist just randomly taking photos and not asking so their lack of smiles can be understood. 

So please smile and ask before you take a photo and also please stay overnight.

title: Perhaps we were lucky, but there were very few other tourists the day we went
text: On a private tour, we did the "typical" drive from Cotonou to the lake and took a motorboat over to Ganvié.  When we approached the village on stilts over the water, a large number of boats and canoes was congregated, full of people singing and carrying religious voodoo symbols. It was a festival day for the voodoo religion. Our guide passed a couple of bills to the leader and the resistance to our photo-taking disappeared.  Shortly after, we came upon an evangelical Christian church, also full of people, song and dance.  We were welcome to join them.  After exploring the canals and buildings, we stopped at Chez M, a hotel and eatery that has a surprisingly interesting gift shop.  We were back at the dock to return to Cotonou in a total of about 2 hours and we really enjoyed it!

title: Ville Touristique Ganvié
text:
Ganvié is a lakeside village of the South of Benin, situated on the lake Nokoué in the North of the metropolis of Cotonou. 
Nicknamed " Venice of Africa ", it includes a few thousand wooden compartments, set up on pilotis and count approximately 30 000 inhabitants today who live mainly on the peach, but more and more also on the tourism. The tourist development of the lake began under the aegis of the inhabitants and by means of some NGO (development of the landing stage for strolls in dugout, souvenir shops, small business crafts, guides, coffees...). Ganvié is the most important lakeside city of western Africa today.

title: Unique - well almost
text: I started to give this a five-star rating but held off not so much that it is not worthwhile rather simply because it is a situation where the lives of the local people are part of the show and they do not get any direct benefit from it.  That aside, there are other stilted cities such as in Brunei, but this certainly has an African flair to it.  The fisherman casting their nets, the water borne markets, it is all enchanting . . . for the tourist.

title: Like nowhere else - worth a visit!
text:
Ganvié is a stilt village and unlike Venice is not connected with each house/building remaining separate from each other. It is explored by boat and we felt the cheaper and more traditional pirogue option was best (no gas fumes or noise!). Prices are fixed and displayed on arrival - you will get a receipt.

You can see much of daily life both on the way to the village and as you go round - again you need to ask a lot of questions. Although some reviews suggested not to get a guide - we did and felt for us this was a great way to learn more about what we were seeing. We requested not to be taken to lots of souvenir shops and the one we were taken to included a bar where we were able to have a drink and watch local life go by. You can stay in the village but for us we did not feel this was necessary.

title: A ne pas rater
text:
Sous 34° la fraîcheur du lac nokoue est à elle seule une source de bonheur mais arrivé à la "Venise d'Afrique" vous amène encore plus de joie. Voir le marché se former avec toutes ces barques et les produits colorés qu'elles transportent est un spectacle magnifique. 

Destination dans mon top 5 du Bénin
translated_text: At 34°C, the coolness of Lake Nokoue is a source of happiness in itself, but arriving at the "Venice of Africa" brings you even more joy. Seeing the market forming with all these boats and the colorful products they carry is a magnificent spectacle. Destination in my top 5 of Benin

title: Very interesting place to visit, don't bother with a tour guide though
text:
Ganvie is a stilt village in Benin that was formed during the slave trading time as people tried to avoid being kidnapped and sold into slavery. 

It is a very interesting village to visit and has a fascinating history. 

Unfortunately, there are some cowboys around here offering tours and I'm afraid to say that we fell for it. We had a 'tour guide' who couldn't answer any questions we had, but did take us on a boat to each of the tourist shops selling keyrings, etc. on the lake and also the hotel where they showed us a room and told us the price. 

That tour was the biggest waste of time and money. 

Pay someone with a boat to take you for a ride, it will be less frustrating and you'll see the stilt village. 

Read about it beforehand as it's interesting to know what you're looking at, but don't expect a tour guide to be able to tell you anything other than show you where you can buy some tourist tat. 

Enjoy your trip! x

title: Magical Water Community
text: I explored the lake, and the fishing villages and the town of Ganvié, that are all on stilts on it. I went with MP Services and while I'm sure it would have been cheaper to organise each bit of the trip myself, with limited time it was well worth it. The service was seamless and friendly, our guide Boniface was knowledgeable but not overbearing, and the operator agent Charbelle who came with me (not sure if it was because I was a woman alone or to get pictures for the hotel website or both, but I gather it's not standard) was lovely and excellent company. The meal they provided was delicious, and we passed the time between stops with both really fun, genuine conversations and easy silences to drink in the absolutely incredible, unique scenerey. However you get yourself out onto the water off Calavi, do it. I had an exhausting week working in Cotonou and it was the perfect way to relax. I'll treasure the experience for years to come.

However you get yourself out onto the water off Calavi, do it. I had an exhausting week working in Cotonou and it was the perfect way to relax. I'll treasure the experience for years to come.

title: Toller Tagesausflug
text: Mit Motorboot oder Baumboot schippert man gemütlich durch die Fischanlagen zum Ort Ganvié. Hier geht es durch kleine und große Kanäle. Neben den Pfahlbauten und Moschee sind auch die Neuerungen zu begutachten (Schule, Hospital etc.). Ein kleiner Stop im Restaurant mit Shop gegenüber der Wasserverteilstation lohnt.
translated_text: Mit Motorboot or Baumboot schippert man gemütlich durch die Fischanlagen zum Ort Ganvié. Yesterday it was a small and large channel. Neben den Pfahlbauten und Moschee sind auch die Neuerungen zu begutachten (Schule, Hospital etc.). Ein kleiner Stop im Restaurant mit Shop gegenüber der Wasserverteilstation lohnt.

title: Worth it
text:
It cost CFA25000 and 30 minutes for a car from town to the harbor and CFA18000 for the guide and boat which took another 30 minutes. Quite sure I think I got ripped off but it is a once in a lifetime experience.
There is a small curio shop with good prices and a bar and 'hotel' with very very basic rooms. I would not spend the night and I am a very seasoned traveller. If I know the country better and spoke French I am sure it would be fine.
It would be great of I could speak French so that I could explore the town more but it was amazing none the less.
If you have a few hours to spare it would really make some great memories and amazing photographs await.

title: Very interesting and instructive
text: The boats take a more or less fixed price and the trip takes about 2h overall. The town is very interesting and unique. More fascinating are the fish farming techniques. Definitely worth the trip.
translated_text: The boats take a more or less fixed price and the trip takes about 2h overall. The town is very interesting and unique. More fascinating are the fish farming techniques. Definitely worth the trip.

title: Un Vietnam en Afrique ...
text: Visite tres sympathique de la ville de Ganvié sur pilotis au Bénin qui donne à l'Afrique un air d'Asie...belles photos sont à prévoir.
translated_text: A very pleasant visit to the town of Ganvié on stilts in Benin, which gives Africa an air of Asia...beautiful photos are to be expected.

title: voir a tout prix les villages lacustres du nokoué
text: j'ai voulu voir la Venise d’Afrique comme l'indiquait un ami sur sa page. je suis allé au bénin et je suis allé visiter les villages appelés SO AVA GANVIE et TCHANHOUE sur le lac NOKOUE à la sortie de Cotonou et vraiment c'était super. le guide était très bien il parle anglais et français et il propose même des visites de tous le bénin a travers des circuits. c'est vraiment trop cool. en fait c'est un village sur le lac mais les villageois ont réussi a faire des terres artificielles  pour permettre a leur enfant d'appendre a marché. du coup la visite ne se fait pas que dans une barque. on descend pour marcher aussi dans les maison qui donnent les unes sur les autres.
translated_title: see the lake villages of Nokoué at all costs
translated_text: I wanted to see the Venice of Africa as a friend indicated on his page. I went to Benin and I went to visit the villages called SO AVA GANVIE and TCHANHOUE on Lake NOKOUE at the exit of Cotonou and it was really great. The guide was very good, he speaks English and French and he even offers tours of all of Benin through circuits. It's really cool. In fact, it's a village on the lake but the villagers managed to make artificial land to allow their child to learn to walk. So the visit is not only done in a boat. We also go down to walk in the houses which overlook each other.

title: Hors du temps
text: Ganvié est un lieu hors du temps, nous avons dormi chez M qui est un endroit qui propose un lieu où dormir et qui est actuellement géré par la fille de M . C'est effectivement un lieu très vetuste, pas d'eau courante, pas de drap.....plutot sale mais très depaysant et plaisant....Je crois qu'il ne faut pas faire que passer à Ganvié mais y dormir, le soir le ballet des pirogues est impressionnant et se reveiller le matin au levé du soleil pour voir se village entrer en effervescence est sublime. C'est effectivement un village lacustre très pauvre, inscrit au patrimoine de l'Unesco mais pauvre comme de très tres nombreux villages en Afrique et dans le monde. Le tourisme, quand il est fait intelligemment permet de faire vivre des villageois. Il est de bon ton d'apporter des "cadeaux" pour donner à des enfants, ( bonbons, savons, tube à bulles, etc etc etc) j'ai parcouru de nombreux pays dans le monde et j'ai beaucoup aimé l'atmosphère de Ganvié'........ Allez y et prenez le temps
translated_text: Ganvié is a timeless place, we slept at M's which is a place that offers a place to sleep and which is currently managed by M's daughter. It is indeed a very dilapidated place, no running water, no sheets.....rather dirty but very exotic and pleasant....I think you should not just pass through Ganvié but sleep there, in the evening the ballet of the canoes is impressive and waking up in the morning at sunrise to see this village come to life is sublime. It is indeed a very poor lakeside village, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site but poor like many other villages in Africa and around the world. Tourism, when done intelligently, allows villagers to make a living. It is good form to bring "gifts" to give to children, (candy, soaps, bubble tubes, etc. etc. etc.) I have traveled to many countries in the world and I really liked the atmosphere of Ganvié'........ Go there and take the time

title: Interesting trip from Cotonou
text: Ganvie village itself is worth just seeing from the waterways in a boat.  Getting there from Cotonou most likely means a good view of the fishing in the lagoon and some of the city as well, including Dankopta Market.
translated_text: Ganvie village itself is worth just seeing from the waterways in a boat.  Getting there from Cotonou most likely means a good view of the fishing in the lagoon and some of the city as well, including Dankopta Market.

title: Very Worthwhile Visit
text: This is a fascinating trip to take if you can. You travel by a wooden flat bottomed boat out the village that rests on stilts in the lake. On the way out you see fishermen, people "commuting" to the mainland, and some wildlife. Once at the village you can see that most of the buildings rest on stilts over the water. There are a couple of structures on dry land, but these are not numerous. There is a small shop and nightclub that we stopped at and they have some good handicraft items. It is quite amazing to see how the town functions on water. It is sort of a very primitive form of Venice (although nowhere near as beautiful - we are seeing wooden huts here). The city arose when people moved away from the coast to escape slavers and it continues to be inhabited into the 21st century.

title: Cidade sobre pilotis
text: O passeio de barco no lago permite visitar a cidade sobre pilotis. A cidade é charmosa, apesar de uma boa parte das casas estar em mau estado. O passeio dentro da cidade é bastante curto, com duas paradas em lojas de souvenir.

title: Molto carino
text:
Dopo qualche decina di minuti di barca a motore si raggiunge il villaggio lacustre di Ganvie, sul lago Nokoue. È una bella esperienza che vi lascerà dei ricordi meravigliosi, soprattutto se ci andrete verso il tramonto. Molto suggestivi i paesaggi, le palafitte, le innumerevoli barche con persone vestite di moltissimi colori il vociare dei bimbi che giocano nell'acqua o dei commercianti che cercano di vendervi qualcosa dalla loro imbarcazione...
Lo spettacolo "folcloristico" che vi presentano al centro del villaggio è un po' scontato, ma pur sempre carino.
translated_text: Dopo take a minute to drive the boat if you reach the lakeside village of Ganvie, on Lake Nokoue. There is a beautiful hope that I will see the light of the cord, so it turns out on the other side. Molto suggestivi i paesaggi, le palafitte, le innumerevoli barche con persone vestite di moltissimi colorsi il vociare dei bimbi che giocano nell'acqua o dei commercianti che cercano di vendervi qualcosa dalla loro imbarcazione... The spettacolo "folcloristico" che vi presentano al centro del villaggio è un po' scontato, ma pur semper carino.

title: Quite facinating
text: It was amazing to see how people can adapt to their landscape and live on the water.  It was great to see how the villagers live and even get to school and work and about their life on the lake.  This was a very memorable area.
translated_text: It was amazing to see how people can adapt to their landscape and live on the water.  It was great to see how the villagers live and even get to school and work and about their life on the lake.  This was a very memorable area.

title: Un villgage lacustre en danger
text:
Sur la côte du Bénin, Ganvié est situé au centre d'un grand marécage menacé par la fragilité de son écho système et par la transformation de zones importantes en cultures.
Cette petite ville lacustre (la plus grand en Afrique) tente de survivre en gardant ses acitivités traditionnelles. atteignable qu'en pirogue, sa découverte reste un moment fort du voyage au Bénin.
Je conseille particulièrement de prendre une chambre dans l'auberge centrale et profiter d'une expérience unique, dormir en voyant l'eau circuler entre les poutres au sol (attention de ne rien laisser tomber...).
Un mode de vie menacé par la civilisation qui mérite d'être entretenu et sauvé par nos visites.
translated_text: On the coast of Benin, Ganvié is located in the center of a large swamp threatened by the fragility of its echo system and by the transformation of large areas into crops. This small lakeside town (the largest in Africa) is trying to survive by maintaining its traditional activities. Reachable only by canoe, its discovery remains a highlight of the trip to Benin. I particularly recommend taking a room in the central inn and enjoying a unique experience, sleeping while watching the water circulate between the beams on the ground (be careful not to drop anything...). A way of life threatened by civilization that deserves to be maintained and saved by our visits.

title: Ganvie ist sicherlich ein Höhepunkt Ihrer Beninreise
text:
Die langsame Fahrt mit der Pirogge zu einem der größten Pfahlbautenkolonien auf dieser Erde wird sie nachhaltig begeistern und ein bleibenden Erinnerungswert haben. Sie sollten jedoch folgendes beachten.
1 Sie haben die Wahl, mit der Piroggeoder mit einem Motorboot durch die Lagune zu fahren. Nehmen Sie auf jeden Fall die Pirogge. Abgesehen davon, dass diese Alternative noch etwas  preiswerter ist, erschließt sich die Schönheit der Lagune nur auf der Pirogge. erst,wenn die Pirogge langsam durch das Schilf gleitet. 
2.Überzeugen Sie sich, dass die Batterie Ihrer Kameras voll geladen ist. Sie kommen beider Vielfalt der einzigartigen Motive in einen Photorausch.
3.An der Ablegestelle kaufen Sie sich einen der breitkrempigen Strohhüte, wenn Sie nicht einen üblen Sonnenbrand erleben wollen,

title: Ganvie dorp op palen in Benin
text:
Niet ver van Cotonou ligt het meer Lac Nokoue, op dit meer is het palendorp Ganvie ontstaan. Volgens overleving is er vroeger een koning geweest met 4 zonen en 1 dochter, bij het overlijden van de koning hebben de zonen land gekregen en de dochter water. De dochter is met haar volgelingen naar het meer getrokken en hebben hun huizen gebouwd midden op het meer en hebben een slimme visteelt opgezet welke nog steeds uitstekend werkt. Op verschillende plaatsen op het meer zijn delen afgezet door takkenbossen in het water te steken, hier kan de jonge vis opgroeien en kan op deze plaatsen niet gevist worden.
De vis die door de mannen gevangen wordt, wordt s'morgens door de vrouwen naar het vasteland gebracht en verkocht zij nemen weer groente e.d. mee retour naar het dorp. Ook nemen zij iedere keer wat grond mee waardoor er eilandjes ontstaan in het dorp. Al het vervoer en markt vindt plaats over of op het water, ook de kinderen leren al op jonge leeftijd met de boten om te gaan.
Het dorp is zeker nog niet overspoeld met toeristen en de bewoners staan positief tegenover toeristen, een bezoek hebben wij als bijzonder ervaren. Dit zijn onvergetelijke excursies!!
Advies: Neem altijd wat water en eten mee voor je zelf en verzorg je zelf goed met kleding en anti muggen spray. Aan de westkust van het meer kan een boot met schipper worden gehuurd om een trip te maken of laat vanuit het hotel een chauffeur meegaan voor een bezoek.

title: nice
text: life inside this lake is crowded and intense. u ll enjoy the sight of villagers everyday life. very recommended
translated_text: life inside this lake is crowded and intense. u ll enjoy the sight of villagers everyday life. very recommended

title: Ballade en pirogue
text: Très jolie visite à faire seul, en groupe ou en famille. La ballade est agréable et intéressante. La cité lacustre est étonnante. Vous verrez des pêcheurs lancer leurs filets. Le prix est à négocier comme tout en Afrique mais on passe un bon moment. Essayer de trouver un piroguier qui parle français pour avoir quelques explications. On peut s'y rendre en taxi sur la journée depuis Cotonou.
translated_text: A very nice visit to do alone, in a group, or with family. The walk is pleasant and interesting. The lakeside town is amazing. You'll see fishermen casting their nets. The price is negotiable, like everything else in Africa, but you'll have a good time. Try to find a canoeist who speaks French to get some explanations. You can get there by taxi during the day from Cotonou.

title: Lac Nokué sans le Pont des Soupirs
text: Superbe glissade, lente et calme, dans les embouteillages de la Venise d'Afrique. Nuit (difficile mais ça vaut la peine) à passer sur place, par exemple chez M.
translated_title: Lake Nokue without the Bridge of Sighs
translated_text: A superb, slow and calm slide through the traffic jams of the Venice of Africa. A night (difficult but worth it) to spend there, for example at Mr.

title: Incontournable...
text:
Si vous séjournez à Cotonou, vous devez faire une ballade en pirogue ( à moteur, rassurez vous...)  sur le lac Nokoué et vous diriger vers le village lacustre de Ganvié, ancien village construit sur la lagune pour échapper autrefois aux rois aux chasseurs d'esclaves.
C'est un endroit incontournable de Cotonou.
Aujourd'hui, il existe des tumulus de terre sur lesquels les habitants peuvent marcher un peu, mais autrefois c'était un village essentiellement lacustre.
On s'y déplace en pirogue. C'est poétique, c'est étrange, c'est totalement dépaysant.
Vous y verrez des lanceurs d'éperviers jetant leur filet pour la mémoire  de votre appareil photo. C'est beau, le geste est  très esthétique...Mais n'oubliez pas de donner un petit quelque chose.

Il y a un "hôtel" sur le lac, un "restaurant"... On peut y boire un verre aussi mais...c'est...Disons...Poétique... ( privilégiez les bouteilles bien bouchées)
translated_text: If you are staying in Cotonou, you must take a trip in a canoe (motorized, don't worry...) on Lake Nokoué and head towards the lakeside village of Ganvié, an ancient village built on the lagoon to escape the kings and slave hunters. It is a must-see place in Cotonou. Today, there are earth mounds on which the inhabitants can walk a little, but in the past it was essentially a lakeside village. People travel there by canoe. It's poetic, it's strange, it's totally exotic. You will see cast net throwers throwing their nets for the memory of your camera. It's beautiful, the gesture is very aesthetic... But don't forget to give a little something. There is a "hotel" on the lake, a "restaurant"... You can have a drink there too but... it's... Let's say... Poetic... (choose well-stoppered bottles)
